item.title: True Detective
item.description: rust: look. i consider myself a realist, all right, but in philosophical terms, i’m what’s called a pessimist. martin:Â um, okay. what’s that mean? rust:Â means i’m bad at parties. martin:Â heh. let me tell you. you ain’t great outside of parties either. rust:Â i think human consciousness was a tragic misstep in evolution. we became too self-aware. nature created an aspect of nature separate from itself. we are creatures that should not exist by natural law. martin:Â huh. that sounds god-fucking-awful, rust. rust:Â we are things that labor under the illusion of having a self, this accretion of sensory experience and feeling, programmed with total assurance that we are each somebody when, in fact, everybody’s nobody. martin:Â i wouldn’t go around spouting that shit, i was you. people around here don’t think that way. i don’t think that way. rust:Â i think the honorable thing for species to do is deny our programming, stop reproducing, walk hand in hand into extinction, one last midnight, brothers and sisters opting out of a raw deal. martin:Â so what’s the point of getting out bed in the morning? rust:Â i tell myself i bear witness, but the real answer is that it’s obviously my programming, and i lack the constitution for suicide.

item.title: Scott Forstall
item.description: Starting in 2000 with Mac OS X, Appleâ€™s desktop operating system has been Unix-based. Why is this significant? Many developers were already familiar with the Unix operating system. With a Unix base, coders could use standard Unix commands in the command line, there was greater code portability, and Mac OS X got all of the associated benefits of Unix. For example, Unix is architected in a modular fashion, which can be beneficial when it comes to system security.

item.title: Bjarne Stroustrup
item.description: Know your fundamentals (algorithms, data structures, machine architecture, systems) and know several programming languages to the point where you can use them idiomatically. Know some non-computer field of study well â€” math, biology, history, optics, whatever. Learn to communicate effectively in speech and in writing. Spend an unreasonable amount of time on some difficult topic to really master it. Try to do something that might make a difference in the world.

item.title: Game Center & Achievements for Apps!
item.description:

David Chartier nails a great idea. Iâ€™d love to make Game Center-shareable achievements in Instapaper, but I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s any chance that Apple would approve it, even after todayâ€™s improvements. (via marco)

item.title: A week with Google Chrome
item.description:
nikf:

In the five years that Iâ€™ve used a Mac, Iâ€™ve had two browsers of choice: Camino, and then with Safari 3â€™s arrival Safari. I know that folks swear by Firefox, but I donâ€™t - and typically find myself swearing at Firefox. Whilst the Mozilla folks have done a fine job of making it look like a Mac app, it never seems for feel and behave like a Mac application. Part of my Safari preference is that I also have a teeny bit of a crush for WebKit, the engine that powers Safari with its CSS animations and long-supported (much clichÃ©d) rounded corners.
